original_title: Sri Lanka stocks surge 1.25-pct, led by banks
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The Colombo Stock Exchange’s All Share Price Index (ASPI) continued to trade higher surpassing the 20,400 mark on Monday, data showed.
“Market was very positive today. Investor interest in the banking sector was seen. Almost all the banks went up,” Ranjan Ranatunga, Assistant Vice President – Research at First Capital said.
The ASPI rose 1.25 percent, or 252.16 points higher from Friday to close at 20,470.52; the S&P SL20 index climbed 1.76 percent, or 103.60 points, to close at 5,998.44.
“Banking sector rose on positive quarterly results,” Ranatunga said. “Interest was also seen in retail and high net worth shares.”

The ASPI was pushed higher on Commercial Bank which ended 7.75 rupees stronger at 189; Carson Cumberbatch which rose 105.50 rupees to 746; Melstacorp which ended 5 rupees up at 165; John Keells Holdings which moved 50 cents up to 23.50 rupees; and DFCC Bank which closed 5.75 rupees higher at 166.
Turnover fell to 7.7 billion rupees from 9.5 billion rupees, while the share volume was 247,608,865.
“Turnover was very good today. It was above the monthly average of 6.4 billion rupees.”

Elsewhere, Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 index surpassed the psychological 43,700 mark hitting record high levels for the second consecutive session as investor optimism surrounding domestic economy and hopes for an interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve were expected, Japan’s The Mainichi newspaper said.
The index moved 0.77 percent, or 336.00 points higher, to 43,714.31.
The Pakistan Stock Exchange’s KSE 100 Index was trading 1.03 percent stronger at 148,003.52.
Meanwhile, India’s Nifty 50 rose 1.00 percent to 24,876.95, while the BSE Sensex was 0.84 percent up at 81,273.75.
As at 3.35 pm Sri Lankan time, spot gold was trading at 3,363.03 US dollars, up 19.75 US dollars. (Colombo/Aug18/2025)
